attributes.description: Prince of Ayodhyá and son of Da[aratha; the hero who slays Tá aká.
The 'son of Ku[ik' and a mighty seer who mentors Ráma and bestows celestial weapons.
A spirit possessing the strength of a thousand elephants, cursed to be a man-eating monster.
The Supreme Lord who took the form of a Dwarf to defeat King Bali.
The 'Thousand-eyed' King of Gods who slew Namuchi and purified the lands of Malaja and Karúsha.
A celebrated saint who cursed Tá aká and Márícha.
The demon king, son of Virochan, who ruled the three worlds before being defeated by VishGu.
A holy river born from Brahmá's will, flowing from Lake Mánas.
Also known as Siddháshrama; the site of VishGu's penance and Vi[vámitra's sacrifice.
The sacred, mind-born lake of Brahmá located near Mount Kailása.

attributes.context: Vi[vámitra acts as the preceptor, guiding Ráma and awarding him divine weapons.
Ráma slays Tá aká with a crescent-shaped dart to protect the Bráhmans and kine.
VishGu, in his Dwarf (Vamana) avatar, used three steps to reclaim the universe from Bali.
Márícha is the giant son of Tá aká and Sunda.
The saint Agastya cursed Tá aká to lose her fair form and become a man-eater.
The Sarjú river originates from the sacred Lake Mánas.
